title: Inside home of ‘worst hoarder ever seen’ as she is evicted
text:
Susan Ralphs, 70, was told her house was a fire hazard (Picture: Andrew Price/ View Finder)

A pensioner and her three cats have been forced to live in a van after she was evicted from her bungalow for hoarding too much.

Susan Ralphs, 70, was told by firefighters that her house had become a hazard and was the ‘worst hoarding they had ever seen’.

An eviction order was then granted by Caernarfon county court, in North Wales, with the retired artist and beauty therapist unable to appeal the decision.

On Monday, bailiffs hired by housing association Adra arrived at the property in Blaenau Ffestiniog, Snowdonia, and Ms Ralphs briefly barricaded herself in before allowing them access.

Three police officers were also called to the house and the locks were changed as she was forced to leave.

She barricaded herself inside the property when the bailiffs came (Picture: Andrew Price/ View Finder)

Firefighters told her it was the worst case of hoarding they’d seen (Picture: Andrew Price/ View Finder)

Ms Ralphs, who suffers from PTSD and other health issues, said she had endured a ‘sleepless night hoping for a last minute change of mind’.

She said: ‘I’m staying positive mentally. Though fragile I’m not going to be angry or bitter. I’m getting in touch with my MP Liz Saville-Roberts for some advice.

Cocktease and whatevs among new words added to Oxford English Dictionary

‘I don’t want to be re-housed, just to regain the home I’ve enjoyed for the last four years with my three lovely cats.

‘I’m 70, a retired professional and I’d like some respect for my dignity and sanity.’

Photos from inside Ms Ralphs’ home show the rooms piled high with furniture, bags and belongings, leaving virtually no space to move around.

Ms Ralphs said she had previously downsized from a five bedroom house (Picture: Andrew Price/ View Finder)

She says her health prevented her from sorting the house (Picture: Andrew Price/ View Finder)

Speaking before her eviction, the pensioner said she had been planning on sorting the house out, but her health had failed.

She said: ‘All I want is to sit in my beloved home with my cats and see the sun and stars from my garden.

‘I am a bit of a hoarder, and the fire brigade officers who have been here say it’s the worst hoarding they have ever seen and that it’s a fire risk.

‘Mostly it’s because I moved here from a place that had five bedrooms, so I have lots of bags of clothes, bedding and curtains, but I am very hygienic.’

She added: ‘I feel like a donkey dragged 400 miles through the Sahara then being kicked and punched instead of being able to reach the oasis for water.

The locks were changed on the property on Monday (Picture: Andrew Price/ View Finder)

She has now been forced to live in a van while she finds a new home (Picture: Andrew Price/ View Finder)

‘I’m so happy here with my cats and their feline friends. My neighbours are animal lovers, too.

‘I’m a quiet and submissive spinster just getting over a run of bad luck. I don’t smoke, drink or take drugs – but the system has walked out on me. No one is helping me.’

A spokesperson for Adra said: ‘Our priority is always to support and sustain tenancies and we work with partner agencies to try and prevent homelessness.

‘We only take legal action as a last resort. In this case, the court decided that the granting of possession was reasonable and proportionate.’

Plaid Cymru MP Mrs Saville-Roberts said: ‘I will do everything I can to help her. No one wants to see a 70-year-old in the street.

‘What she needs is some intensive support and to be able to keep her possessions.’

description: Susan Ralphs, 70, was evicted from her home in Blaenau Ffestiniog, Snowdonia, Wales, and will now live in a van.
